responses.content:

The premise is: "If Mary was at the wedding, then Sue was at the wedding."
The conclusion is: "If Sue was at the wedding, then Mary was at the wedding."

The logical form of this argument is:
Premise: If P, then Q
Conclusion: If Q, then P

This logical form is known as the "converse" of the original implication.

The converse of an implication is not always logically valid. In other words, just because the original implication "If P, then Q" is true, it does not necessarily mean that the converse "If Q, then P" is also true.
